articles.headline: Israeli Strikes Kill 7 Aid Workers in Gaza
articles.snippet: The attack on clearly marked vehicles run by the World Central Kitchen shows how dangerous relief work has been during the war, and adds fuel to accusations that Israel has bombed indiscriminately.
articles.abstract: The attack on clearly marked vehicles run by the World Central Kitchen shows how dangerous relief work has been during the war, and adds fuel to accusations that Israel has bombed indiscriminately.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli strikes on an aid convoy run by the charity group World Central Kitchen killed seven of its workers in the Gaza Strip, setting off international outrage and underscoring the risks to humanitarian workers trying to alleviate a looming famine.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: The U.S. Is Rebuilding a Legal Pathway for Refugees. The Election Could Change That.
articles.snippet: President Biden is restoring resources and staffing for the refugee program, which was gutted during the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: President Biden is restoring resources and staffing for the refugee program, which was gutted during the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: With national attention focused on the chaos at the southern border, President Biden has been steadily rebuilding a legal pathway for immigration that was gutted during the Trump administration.

articles.headline: How Soccer Learned to Embrace Ramadan: From Faked Injuries to Bespoke Diets
articles.snippet: In competitions like the Premier League, Muslim pros who once faced pressure to avoid daily fasts during the monthlong holiday now benefit from custom diets and in-game breaks.
articles.abstract: In competitions like the Premier League, Muslim pros who once faced pressure to avoid daily fasts during the monthlong holiday now benefit from custom diets and in-game breaks.

articles.headline: Biden and Corporate America? It’s ‘Complicated.’
articles.snippet: The president has courted executives with long listening sessions and sustained outreach, but frustrated many with his tax plans and regulations.
articles.abstract: The president has courted executives with long listening sessions and sustained outreach, but frustrated many with his tax plans and regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the days before delivering his State of the Union speech last month, President Biden called the chief executives of General Motors and Cisco Systems to ask their advice on the state of the American economy and share how he planned to talk about it.

articles.headline: Switching From iPhone to Android Is Easy. It’s the Aftermath That Stings.
articles.snippet: Even if you manage to ditch your iPhone, Apple’s hooks are still there.
articles.abstract: Even if you manage to ditch your iPhone, Apple’s hooks are still there.
articles.lead_paragraph: When I temporarily switched from an iPhone to an Android phone last week, I was bracing for a world of hurt. I’ve owned only Apple phones ever since buying the first-generation iPhone in 2007. And, like many, I’ve bought other Apple products that pair nicely, including AirPods, an Apple Watch and an iPad.

articles.headline: Disney Fends Off Activist Investor for Second Time in 2 Years
articles.snippet: Nelson Peltz had campaigned for two seats on Disney’s board of directors, as he sought to shake up the company’s growth plan.
articles.abstract: Nelson Peltz had campaigned for two seats on Disney’s board of directors, as he sought to shake up the company’s growth plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: The activist investor Nelson Peltz and Ike Perlmutter, the former chairman of Marvel Entertainment, have failed to infiltrate Disney’s board for the second time in two years, losing a tensely fought contest for support of the company’s shareholders as part of a campaign to alter its direction.

articles.headline: Zelensky Lowers Ukraine’s Draft Age, Risking Political Backlash
articles.snippet: The idea of requiring more men to join the fight against Russia’s invasion has become toxic, but Russia is not relenting in its assault.
articles.abstract: The idea of requiring more men to join the fight against Russia’s invasion has become toxic, but Russia is not relenting in its assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has signed into law three measures aimed at replenishing the ranks of his country’s exhausted and battered army, including the politically poisonous step of lowering the age when men become eligible for mobilization, and eliminating some medical exemptions.

articles.headline: Taiwan’s Strongest Earthquake in 25 Years Kills 9 and Injures Hundreds
articles.snippet: The magnitude-7.4 quake was followed by more than 200 aftershocks. Dozens of people were trapped. Two buildings in the city of Hualien teetered perilously.
articles.abstract: The magnitude-7.4 quake was followed by more than 200 aftershocks. Dozens of people were trapped. Two buildings in the city of Hualien teetered perilously.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first quake was alarming enough — a rumble more powerful than anything felt in Taiwan for a quarter-century, lasting for more than a minute on Wednesday morning, knocking belongings and even whole buildings askew. It was so strong it set off tsunami warnings in Japan, China and the Philippines.
articles.byline: By Meaghan Tobin, Victoria Kim, Chris Buckley, Mike Ives, Siyi Zhao and John Yoon
